docTitle.titlePart:
Correlation of CD34
þ Cells with Tissue Angiogenesis
after Traumatic Brain Injury in a Rat Model

byline.docAuthor:
Xinbin Guo,
1 Li Liu,
1 Ming Zhang,
2 Angela Bergeron,
3 Zhuang Cui,
1 Jing-Fei Dong,
3 and Jianning Zhang
1

front.div:
Abstract
Increasing evidence suggests that circulating endothelial progenitor cells, which are a subpopulation of hemato-
poietic progenitor CD34
þ cells, play a critical role in neovascularization and tissue repair. We have tested the
hypothesis that traumatic brain injury (TBI) could mobilize CD34
þ cells to peripheral blood and brain tissue, a
process critical for vascular repair, in a rat model of TBI. Male Wistar rats were subjected to controlled fluid
percussion. Blood and brain tissue were collected before and after TBI to measure the levels of CD34
þ cells in
peripheral blood and to detect their accumulation in the damaged cerebral tissue. Compared with surgery
controls, CD34
þ cells significantly increased in the peripheral blood and accumulated in the brain tissue of TBI
rats. Immunohistochemistry detected new vessels with incomplete CD34
þ endothelial-like cell lining and an
increased number of microvessels in the injured and surrounding tissue. The results demonstrate a close cor-
relation between an increase in circulating CD34
þ cells in response to traumatic injury and angiogenesis in TBI
rat brain. They also suggest that transplantation of CD34
þ cells or augmentation of endogenous CD34
þ cells may
be a novel therapeutic approach for patients with TBI.
front.keyword:
Key words: angiogenesis; CD34
þ cells; endothelial progenitor cells; traumatic brain injury
